RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possuo doutorado em Fsica (Elementary Particle Theory), International School for Advanced Studies (2012), Trieste, Italy. Tenho experincia na rea da Fsica das partculas elementares. Estou atuando nessa area presso Carleton University em Ottawa, Canada.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: I have a PhD degree in Elementary Particle Theory from International School for Advanced Studies (2012). I have experience in the field of theoretical particle physics. I am currently a postdoctoral fellow at Carleton University, Ottawa, Canada.

LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.TITULO-DA-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA: Investigation of the impact of beyond the Standard Model physics on LHC observables using effective field theory
LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.OBJETIVOS-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA: The main result obtained by the experimental collaborations ATLAS and CMS during the first three years (2010-2013, Run 1) of the CERN Large Hadron Collider was the discovery of a new boson with a mass of about 125 GeV. A great effort has been made by two experimental collaborations in the attempt to define the properties of this new particle. The results point in favor of a Higgs boson as described by the SM. This was a great triumph: the main block missing for experimental validation of the SM is now in place. On the other hand there is no evidence that new particles have been observed during LHC Run 1 and the experimental collaborations established limits on new physics scale for different models beyond the SM. These analyses indicate that new physics particles must have masses greater than roughly 1 TeV. In summer 2015 the second LHC run has begun and the next three years (2015-2018, Run 2) will be crucial for the particle physics community because the LHC will provide important information about the existence of new physics at the TeV scale. Under the assumption that the new physics lies at energy scales much larger than the electro-weak scale, the effects of physics beyond the SM on low energy observable can be captured by the addition of a set of higher dimensional operator to the Lagrangian of the SM. The main contributions to the physics of the LHC are given by dimension-6 operators. New physics effects are most promising to manifest themselves in interactions involving heavy SM particles, like the top quark and the Higgs boson. The goal of my research is to study the effect of dimension-6 operators on LHC observable that involve these particles. The aim is to conduct a complete investigation of all operators of the effective theory that are relevant and provide a comprehensive statistical analysis in terms of numerical codes, considering both total cross sections and differential distributions.
LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.TITULO-DA-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA-INGLES: Investigation of the impact of beyond the Standard Model physics on LHC observables using effective field theory
LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.OBJETIVOS-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA-INGLES: The main result obtained by the experimental collaborations ATLAS and CMS during the first three years (2010-2013, Run 1) of the CERN Large Hadron Collider was the discovery of a new boson with a mass of about 125 GeV. A great effort has been made by two experimental collaborations in the attempt to define the properties of this new particle. The results point in favor of a Higgs boson as described by the SM. This was a great triumph: the main block missing for experimental validation of the SM is now in place. On the other hand there is no evidence that new particles have been observed during LHC Run 1 and the experimental collaborations established limits on new physics scale for different models beyond the SM. These analyses indicate that new physics particles must have masses greater than roughly 1 TeV. In summer 2015 the second LHC run has begun and the next three years (2015-2018, Run 2) will be crucial for the particle physics community because the LHC will provide important information about the existence of new physics at the TeV scale. Under the assumption that the new physics lies at energy scales much larger than the electro-weak scale, the effects of physics beyond the SM on low energy observable can be captured by the addition of a set of higher dimensional operator to the Lagrangian of the SM. The main contributions to the physics of the LHC are given by dimension-6 operators. New physics effects are most promising to manifest themselves in interactions involving heavy SM particles, like the top quark and the Higgs boson. The goal of my research is to study the effect of dimension-6 operators on LHC observable that involve these particles. The aim is to conduct a complete investigation of all operators of the effective theory that are relevant and provide a comprehensive statistical analysis in terms of numerical codes, considering both total cross sections and differential distributions.

LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.TITULO-DA-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA: Applications of the Exact Renormalization Group Equation
LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.OBJETIVOS-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA: The Exact Renormalization Group Equation is a powerful tool that is widely used to study, in principle, nonperturbatively the infrared and ultraviolet properties of any quantum field theory. In particular, this functional flow equation is usually used to study the existence of fixed points for theories that have applications in statistical mechanics, quantum gravity and high energy physics. Effective field theories are usually defined with a physical cutoff that sets the high energy limit for the validity of the theory. At scales of order of the cutoff some physical quantities starts to not behave properly, violating for example unitarity. Recently there have been some suggestions that nonperturbative effects may actually heal effective field theories of these problems. One possibility is that the renormalization group of the theory has a fixed point and the real world correspond to a trajectory that ends at the fixed point in the ultraviolet. This is known as Asymptotic Safety and its equivalent to a nonperturbativative notion of renormalizability. As emphasized by Weinberg, in discussing Asymptotic Safety it would be best to define the couplings directly in terms of observable quantities. Since it is much easier to define the running of couplings defined as coefficients of field monomials in the Lagrangian, so far most of the work has concentrated on the latter. One might expect that a fixed point for the Lagrangian coefficients would translate also in a fixed point for couplings defined in more physical terms. The aim of this research is to develop studies in this direction. The goal is to provide consistent calculations of physical observables for theories that present non-trivial phase diagrams, using the Exact Renormalization Group Equation, in order to show that the good behavior of the couplings as a function of some RG scale reflects itself into a good behavior of physical amplitudes as a function of external momenta.
LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.TITULO-DA-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA-INGLES: Applications of the Exact Renormalization Group Equation
LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.OBJETIVOS-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA-INGLES: The Exact Renormalization Group Equation is a powerful tool that is widely used to study, in principle, nonperturbatively the infrared and ultraviolet properties of any quantum field theory. In particular, this functional flow equation is usually used to study the existence of fixed points for theories that have applications in statistical mechanics, quantum gravity and high energy physics. Effective field theories are usually defined with a physical cutoff that sets the high energy limit for the validity of the theory. At scales of order of the cutoff some physical quantities starts to not behave properly, violating for example unitarity. Recently there have been some suggestions that nonperturbative effects may actually heal effective field theories of these problems. One possibility is that the renormalization group of the theory has a fixed point and the real world correspond to a trajectory that ends at the fixed point in the ultraviolet. This is known as Asymptotic Safety and its equivalent to a nonperturbativative notion of renormalizability. As emphasized by Weinberg, in discussing Asymptotic Safety it would be best to define the couplings directly in terms of observable quantities. Since it is much easier to define the running of couplings defined as coefficients of field monomials in the Lagrangian, so far most of the work has concentrated on the latter. One might expect that a fixed point for the Lagrangian coefficients would translate also in a fixed point for couplings defined in more physical terms. The aim of this research is to develop studies in this direction. The goal is to provide consistent calculations of physical observables for theories that present non-trivial phase diagrams, using the Exact Renormalization Group Equation, in order to show that the good behavior of the couplings as a function of some RG scale reflects itself into a good behavior of physical amplitudes as a function of external momenta.
